content: In the testcases, only lowercase words appear, whereas in validators, several contain uppercase letters. Please change this
Please add a test case with Mixed case... or remove mixed case from validators
The constraint "0 < string < 10" should be revised as "0 < length of string < 10".

avoid using read word:string(10)
for the stub generator because word is a definition name in pascal language

read s:string(10) is better for shortest code contest anyway
Good idea but specify in the Goal that result is lowercase not only that "Case-sensitivity doesn't matter"

Nice idea but strange tests. In tests 2 & 3 you have words that are entirely lowercase or uppercase, in the validators you have mixed case. A validator should resemble the test for a similar input without adding extra functionality. It's also not clear at all that the output for validator 3 should be 'e' and not 'E'. If it happened in a normal test then the assignment would be clearer.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash, many ways to optimize the size of code and learn something.

I still have a remark about the Goal description, and then the ouput: why do you precise "you need to explain why [...] a word isn't abecedarian" ? We don't have to precise why in the answer as there is only 1 answer: the letter isn't abecedian.

To simplify the goal description and allow the possibility to even more reduce the code size, i suggest you to change the output by just printing the problematic letter:
"pot", print "o"
"lot", print "True".

Anyways, i approve your clash.

Error on validator 3, without any errors on the Test cases:

Found: False: i comes before P
Expected: False: i comes before p

I think ensuring that they cast casing in output adds unwanted complexity / confusion to the puzzle..
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
To decrease difficulty you can set the output to true or false only
Fine clash, but for long not-abecedarian word there are multiple explanation. The "abecedarian" or "not abecedarian" outpud should be enough, in my opinion.

Note: in python you can compare characters directly: 
'a' < 'b' == True

No need for ord() conversion.

I like this clash but the output is not clear.
For example in booster, I print "False: e comes before o". Which I think matches the statement. But the answer is "False: e comes before t". Which is correct too.

To me there are multiple correct answers. And a rule is missing to select the good one.
perfect clash of code but i think you should clarify in the statment that when printing the reason why its not abeced... the letters are the one next to each other and not in order
I like this one.  I think it has a good amount of interest and complexity for a clash.

the output has a huge chunk that needs to be hardcoded and that's usually kinda meh for shortest
also put some constraints ie max string length
I pared down the output and added the suggested constraint. Thank-you for the feedback.

I have changed it so that you only need to output with the first letter that is out of order. This way there is only one correct output for every case. The first letter will never be out of order as it kind of "establishes" the order.
CoC should not have binary outputs (yes/no or true/false).
OK. I changed the input on that validator to remove the uppercase. Wasn't intentionally trying to be case-sensitive.
Thank-you. I took your suggestions and made the output either "True" or simply the first letter out of place.

Case-sensitivity refers to the fact that capital letters and lower case are treated the same. We only care if in alphabetical order (like, you can't just compare raw ASCII values for the letters). I added that the output should be in lower case.
Yes. This is terrible. I got 100% on test cases in shortest mode, so never added case-handling. I got 0% on validators! So annoying.
Testcase 3 has uppercase letters. But I added another.
